Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story:
I was deep into the code, fingers flying across the keyboard, when my phone buzzed. The new feature was almost done, but the code review had just flagged some performance issues. My team expected me to fix them before the end of the day—clean, efficient code was non-negotiable. I was already feeling the pressure when a message popped up from Sam: “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m totally lost with this furniture and the instructions make no sense.”

I stared at the screen, torn. Sam had just moved in and didn’t know anyone else in town. He’d helped me out last year when I was sick, and I knew he was counting on me now. But the code review comments were piling up, and my lead had already reminded me twice about the importance of this release. My mind raced, guilt and anxiety twisting together. I wanted to be there for Sam, but I also couldn’t let my team down. The clock ticked, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding an answer I wasn’t sure I could give.
